>From: Derek James <blue5432@...>
>
>Flightless birds are another example.  So are
>cave-dwelling lizards who evolve away pigmentation or
>eyes.  These simpler morphologies require less energy
>and upkeep, and produce fitter organisms for that
>particular environment.

Just an observation:  These are evolutionary simplifications in a CHANGING 
environment.  When using NEAT on a fixed domain, simplification shouldn't be 
necessary, right?  At least not if there is a large enough population to 
make an effective search.  It is only when the problem changes that a 
simplification may prove beneficial.

On the other hand, with a sufficiently complex genome, features may develop 
that increase fitness, but render another feature irrelevant.  It may even 
render it inhibitory.  The overall fitness still went up, but it could go up 
even further if it could shed the unnecessary components.  Thus a balance of 
increasing AND decreasing complexity could prove beneficial, even in an 
unchanging environment.

But that really depends on the environment and the task.  Control over a 
fixed-topology robot probably won't benefit from it.  But if the robot could 
grow a new sensor, rendering an old sensor meaningless, then shedding the 
power drain of the old sensor would increase fitness.

But for most forms of simplification, simply reducing weights is 
functionally equivalent, is it not?  If you have a fixed number of inputs, 
some of which are not relevant, then learning a weight of 0 is equivalent to 
simplifying them out of the genome, right?
